<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>

<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_Posix_BinSemAcquireMutex:
```c
int32 OS_Posix_BinSemAcquireMutex(pthread_mutex_t *mut)
{
    struct timespec timeout;

    if (clock_gettime(CLOCK_REALTIME, &timeout) != 0)
    {
        return OS_SEM_FAILURE;
    }

    timeout.tv_sec += OS_POSIX_BINSEM_MAX_WAIT_SECONDS;

    if (pthread_mutex_timedlock(mut, &timeout) != 0)
    {
        return OS_SEM_FAILURE;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>

...
#define OS_SEM_FAILURE (-6)
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No invariant controlling expressions found. The only controlling constructs are two if statements: "if (clock_gettime(CLOCK_REALTIME, &timeout) != 0)" and "if (pthread_mutex_timedlock(mut, &timeout) != 0)" — both depend on runtime function return values and therefore are not invariant. There are no loops in this function (so the rule exceptions for infinite loops or constant do-while are irrelevant). The use of the constant OS_POSIX_BINSEM_MAX_WAIT_SECONDS (defined as 2) only appears in the assignment "timeout.tv_sec += OS_POSIX_BINSEM_MAX_WAIT_SECONDS;" which is not a controlling expression. The macro return values (OS_SEM_FAILURE, OS_SUCCESS) are constant but only used as return values, not as controlling expressions. Therefore no code fragments in the provided function require investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3.
